Today's Project

Part of Week 2 : Project 2 : Movie Directory.

Hashes

What Is It?

Hashes are the most common data storage unit you're going to see. Even when you aren't using hashes, you're probably using a type of data storage that looks an awful lot like a hash.

How Does It Work?

A hash is a data storage unit that is composed of what are called "keys" and "values". Each key is connected to value. Unlike an array, there is no order in which the key-value pair is added into hash, nor can the information be extracted by knowing the order in which the key-value pair was added. If you know the key, you can find the value. If you add a key, you also have to add a value.

So first, how do we create a hash? One option:

1 irb(main):001:0> fruit = Hash.new
2 => {}
3 irb(main):002:0> fruit
4 => {}

Alternatively, you can just make it equal to the curly brackets:

1 irb(main):001:0> fruit = {}
2 => {}
3 irb(main):002:0> fruit
4 => {}

What can be the key? Anything! Here are some examples:

 1 irb(main):006:0> grocery_list = {}
 2 => {}
 3 irb(main):007:0> grocery_list["fruit"] = "mango"
 4 => "mango"
 5 irb(main):008:0> grocery_list[:fruit] = "apple"
 6 => "apple"
 7 irb(main):009:0> grocery_list[["fruit","salad"]] = "raspberry"
 8 => "raspberry"
 9 irb(main):010:0> grocery_list[1] = "items"
10 => "items"
11 irb(main):011:0> grocery_list[Object.new] = "Thing"
12 => "Thing"
13 irb(main):012:0> grocery_list
14 => {"fruit"=>"mango", :fruit=>"apple", ["fruit", "salad"]=>"raspberry", 1=>"items", #<Object:0x007f8abd95ec10>=>"Thing"}

You can even use variables as keys and values in a hash - or at least the values from the variables:

 1 irb(main):034:0> your_hash = {}
 2 => {}
 3 irb(main):035:0> hash_key = gets.chomp
 4 S
 5 => "S"
 6 irb(main):036:0> hash_value = gets.chomp
 7 B
 8 => "B"
 9 irb(main):037:0> your_hash[hash_key] = hash_value
10 => "B"
11 irb(main):038:0> your_hash 
12 => {"S"=>"B"}

What can be the value? Pretty much anything that can be the key.

How do you add something to a hash? One, you can add a value to hash on creation:

1 irb(main):001:0> students = { "Thomas" => "John", "Robinson" => "Craig" }
2 => {"Thomas"=>"John", "Robinson"=>"Craig"}
3 irb(main):002:0> students
4 => {"Thomas"=>"John", "Robinson"=>"Craig"}

Once you have an existing hash, it is as easy as this:

1 irb(main):003:0> students["Simpson"] = "Homer"
2 => "Homer"
3 irb(main):004:0> students
4 => {"Thomas"=>"John", "Robinson"=>"Craig", "Simpson"=>"Homer"}

Alternatively:

1 irb(main):004:0> students
2 => {"Thomas"=>"John", "Robinson"=>"Craig", "Simpson"=>"Homer"}
3 irb(main):005:0> students.store("Crusoe", "Robinson")
4 => "Robinson"
5 irb(main):006:0> students
6 => {"Thomas"=>"John", "Robinson"=>"Craig", "Simpson"=>"Homer", "Crusoe"=>"Robinson"}

Or you can merge an existing hash with your new hash to add to it:

1 irb(main):010:0> a = {"Brewster" => "Punky"}
2 => {"Brewster"=>"Punky"}
3 irb(main):011:0> students.merge!(a)
4 => {"Thomas"=>"John", "Robinson"=>"Craig", "Simpson"=>"Homer", "Crusoe"=>"Robinson", "Brewster"=>"Punky"}

What if I want to get information out of a hash? There are a number of methods to do so, but none of them that work sequentially as with an array.

If you know the key, it's pretty easy:
